x4codes.hlp: Los Alamos National Laboratory, NM, United States of America

x4freetext: Experiment performed at the
Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE)using 800
MeV proton linac
The gamma rays were detected with the GEANIE
spectrometer, located about 20 m from the neutron
source on the 60deg right flight path. For this
experiment, the GEANIE spectrometer consisted of 11
planar and 15 25% High- purity Ge (HPGe) coaxial
detectors. All of the planars and 9 of the coaxial
detectors were equipped with Compton suppression
shields. The detectors were situated at a distance of
approx. 14 cm from the focal point where the
scattering sample was located.
neutron energy determined by time of flight
method. Detection time of the "flash" of gamma rays
caused by the spallation reaction was used as a
reference marker. The detection time of the gamma rays
produced by neutrons interacting with the sample was
used to calculate the time of flight.
A fission chamber containing  235,238U located 2m
upstream from the GEANIE spectrometer was used to
determine the neutron flux.
Cross section for
production of 847 keV gamma transition was used
for checking purposes in several runs. For this
purpose the 150Sm sample was sandwiched between
0.2mm Fe foils.
Pulsed neutron beam was produced via
spallation on a natural W target by an 800-MeV proton
linear accelerator beam. The average proton beam
current at the spallation target was about 1 - 2
mu-A. The neutron beam structure contained 625 mu-s
long `macropulses` driven by two of every three such
macropulses from the accelerator for an average rate
of 40/s. Each macropulse consisted of `micropulses`
spaced every 1.8 mu-s, each <1 ns long. The pulsed
beam allowed incident neutron energies to be
determined using the time-of-flight technique.
The 150Sm sample with thickness
of 1550 mg/cm2
Corrected for internal conversion and deadtime and
multiple scattering. The internal conversion
coefficients were taken from the NUDAT database
Cross sections for several discrete gamma rays i.e.
334 keV gamma line was already published in 2007 and
compiled in 14148.002.
uncertainty of incident neutron energy
obtained from time-of-flight time resolution
